abstract.p: Letter from former US Under Sec of State Peter Tarnoff disputes Thomas L Friedman's September 11 Op-Ed column on US involvement in Middle East peace process (S)

block.p: By characterizing United States involvement in the Middle East peace process as ''an act of kindness,'' Thomas L. Friedman (column, Sept. 11) forgets both United States commitments to Israel and the risk to American strategic interests if the peace process falters.

By characterizing United States involvement in the Middle East peace process as ''an act of kindness,'' Thomas L. Friedman (column, Sept. 11) forgets both United States commitments to Israel and the risk to American strategic interests if the peace process falters.

However many trips Secretary of State Warren Christopher made to the Middle East, the Clinton Administration facilitated the Israeli-Palestinian Declaration of Principles and the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan, and it defused several potentially violent confrontations between Israel and its neighbors. Failure to bring about peace between Israel and Syria should not obscure the historic gains of the past four years. Indeed, where would Israel be without them today at a time when the peace process is under strain?

Mr. Friedman says that ''the greatest strategic danger to the U.S. in the Middle East comes from Iraq or Iran.'' I agree, but the ability of those regimes to mobilize anti-American and anti-Israeli emotions throughout the region depends on whether or not the peace process is progressing.
The writer was Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, 1993-97.
